title: Ronnie O'Sullivan explains what will make him retire from snooker
text:
Ronnie O’Sullivan could still have a long time left at the top of snooker (Picture: Getty Images)

Ronnie O’Sullivan reckons he could still have 15 years at the top of snooker, but will only continue to play professionally if he believes he can win big tournaments.

The 43-year-old is showing no signs of slowing up after 27 years as a professional, still ranked number two in the world and winning the only event he has entered so far this season, the Shanghai Masters.

The Rocket is back in action this week at the English Open as he looks to reclaim the title he won for the only time in 2017.

The five-time world champion is the favourite with the bookmakers to lift the trophy in Crawley and he says that he will keep turning up as long as he is one of the players fancied to win.

‘With me now, it’s just about playing as much as I can, just enjoying what’s left of my career,’ O’Sullivan told the Press Association. ‘How long that is, I don’t know. It could be five years, it could be 10 years, it could be 15 years.

‘I’ve kind of surprised myself, really, so I’ve stopped trying to have a plan and just accept that every year is a bonus.

‘If I didn’t feel like I could win tournaments, I would probably stop because I haven’t got to that point yet where I’m happy to lose.

‘There’s going to come a time where I might get on the start line and think I’m maybe 10th favourite to win a tournament, where I’m relying on nine people to get beat for me to win a tournament.

‘Maybe that would be the time where I probably think about turning it in. But at the moment, I don’t see it that way.

‘There are a few of us at the top that are sharing victories so as long as every time I’ve got my hat in the ring, I’ve got half a chance then I’ll keep going.’

The Rocket certainly has got his hat in the ring after his thoroughly impressive victory in Shanghai last month, where he ousted Kyren Wilson, Neil Robertson and Shaun Murphy en route to the title.

While O’Sullivan’s first round exit at the World Championship this year grabbed the headlines, his form has been stunning in recent months and continues to be so.

The world number two entered 11 tournaments last season and won five of them, with his Shanghai victory taking his win rate to six from his last 12 events.

O’Sullivan faces Jamie O’Neill in round one in Crawley on Monday evening.
